documentType: Bureau of Prisons internal memorandum and contract modification
summary: This document is a series of internal Bureau of Prisons memoranda and a contract modification related to a major security camera system upgrade at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York in 2018-2019. It details a request to exceed a $10,000 funding limit for a project costing approximately $800,000 to replace failed DVRs and install 272 new cameras. The final part is a 2019 contract modification with vendor Anixter Inc. for related equipment. This document is a government contract and limited-source justification for the procurement and installation of a NICE Vision Professional Smart Video Recorder system at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. The justification cites an urgent and compelling need due to the failure of the existing DVR system, creating safety and security risks. The contract is awarded to SigNet Technologies, Inc. This document contains standard US Department of Justice (DOJ) contract clauses and provisions related to personnel security, residency requirements, confidentiality agreements, and information security for contractors. It outlines requirements for background checks, protection of DOJ information, and compliance with federal security standards. This document is a set of contract clauses, security requirements, and authorization memos from the Federal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) for the purchase and upgrade of a camera system (specifically NICE camera system) at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. It includes detailed IT security protocols for contractors handling DOJ information and authorizes an expenditure of up to $800,000.

keyFacts: In 2018, MCC New York's camera system was critically degraded, with two 96-channel DVRs having repeatedly failed, leaving areas without video coverage and using obsolete, unsupportable technology.
The Bureau of Prisons approved an $800,000 project (MWR #8158) to replace the system with a new 350-channel NVR system and install 272 new cameras to ensure a safe and secure environment.
The project required special approval to exceed a standard $10,000 funding limit for minor work requests, highlighting the scale and urgency of the security upgrade.
A related 2019 contract modification with vendor Anixter Inc. shows ongoing procurement of specific fiber optic and networking equipment (like cable, connectors, patch panels) for the institution.

The document is purely administrative and technical, related to facility infrastructure at a federal prison where Jeffrey Epstein was later held; it contains no direct references to Epstein, his case, or any individuals involved with him.

The Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York's existing 96-channel DVR security system had repeatedly failed, leaving critical areas without video coverage and creating urgent safety and security risks for staff and inmates.
The contract justification states that failure to immediately award the contract would "result in safety and security concerns for staff and inmates and increase liability to the government."

The contract was awarded on a limited-source, non-competitive basis to SigNet Technologies, Inc. for $569,108.99, citing an "urgent and compelling need" and SigNet's unique qualifications as the approved maintainer of BOP systems.
The document notes that public posting of the justification was withheld due to security risks, as revealing the inoperable video system "could potentially endanger inmates and staff safety."
The new NICE Vision system was required to connect to the BOPNET (Bureau of Prisons Network) and follow strict IPv6 protocol standards, which SigNet's system was already approved for.
The document contains standard DOJ contract clauses for contractor security and compliance.
Contractors must ensure no non-U.S. citizens access DOJ information systems without a specific waiver.
Contractors must protect DOJ information and comply with FISMA, NIST standards, and other federal security requirements.
The document prohibits contractors from requiring employees to sign confidentiality agreements that restrict reporting of fraud, waste, and abuse.
Contractors must provide DOJ, including the Office of Inspector General, access to facilities and records for security compliance verification.
The Federal Bureau of Prisons authorized an $800,000 expenditure to upgrade the NICE camera system at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York.
The procurement process involved multiple layers of approval to exceed a standard $50,000 work request funding limit, with final approval granted in September 2018.
The document contains extensive, standard DOJ/BOP contract clauses focusing on IT security, data protection, and compliance requirements for contractors handling sensitive government information.
The vendor Pivot Technologies, with a representative Steve Sernei, provided a detailed quote for the camera system hardware and software upgrades.
The document is primarily a routine government procurement and contract compliance document, with no direct mention of Jeffrey Epstein, his associates, or related criminal activities.
